abstract.p: Bluetooth's wireless stereo headphones, priced at $110, can pick up streaming audio from phones and compatible MP3 players; weigh less than ounce; photo (S)

block.p: Bluetooth stereo headphones don't come much smaller than the Plantronics Pulsar 260. These $110 wireless headphones, which can pick up streaming audio from phones and compatible MP3 players, weigh less than an ounce.

The Pulsar 260, available now online and in retail stores, includes a pair of noise-isolating earbuds, a microphone unit and a ''pod'' with music controls. The battery lasts for up to nine hours on a charge, and the unit can transmit and receive audio as far away as 30 feet.
The Pulsar 260 headphones from Plantronics can pick up streaming audio from as far away as 30 feet.

Bluetooth stereo headphones don't come much smaller than the Plantronics Pulsar 260. These $110 wireless headphones, which can pick up streaming audio from phones and compatible MP3 players, weigh less than an ounce.

The Pulsar 260, available now online and in retail stores, includes a pair of noise-isolating earbuds, a microphone unit and a ''pod'' with music controls. The battery lasts for up to nine hours on a charge, and the unit can transmit and receive audio as far away as 30 feet.

When you are at home, you can use the included adapter to stream music to home stereo systems or receivers. There is a clip on the back of the pod, or the device can be worn around your neck like a high-tech medallion.
Buttons on the pod control volume and -- if your device supports it -- track selection. There is also a standard answer/hang-up button as well as a center mute button.

This Pulsar 260 is designed for use with music-capable cellphones and is not directly compatible with non-Bluetooth music players like the iPod or Zune. It needs a Bluetooth adapter, sold separately, to work with those players. Also, only music plays back in true stereo, so don't expect phone calls to sound like outtakes from a Rolling Stones session.
